olog.title: Liberty Machines: Cybernetics, Autonomy, and the Ethics of Self-Governing Systems

entities.label: Liberty Machine
entities.description: A technical or organizational system designed to support autonomy, adaptability, and ethical self-regulation (cf. Bateson, Wiener, Beer, von Foerster).

entities.label: Cybernetic Feedback
entities.description: The recursive process of sensing, responding, and adapting that underlies self-governing systems (Wiener, Beer).

entities.label: Autonomy
entities.description: The capacity of a system to self-organize, self-regulate, and pursue goals without external control (Beer, von Foerster).

entities.label: Ethical Constraint
entities.description: Norms, values, or principles embedded in or emergent from the system, guiding its actions (Bateson, von Foerster).

entities.label: Viable System Model (VSM)
entities.description: A framework for understanding and designing organizations as adaptive, self-regulating systems (Beer).

entities.label: Observer
entities.description: An agent (human or non-human) who participates in, interprets, and sometimes perturbs the system (Bateson, von Foerster).

entities.label: Environment
entities.description: The external and internal contexts to which liberty machines must adapt and respond (Bateson, Wiener).

morphisms.how: Recursive sensing and responding allow the system to self-organize and adapt.
Self-governance is bounded by internal or emergent norms and values.
morphisms.why: Prevents runaway or destructive behavior (von Foerster).

morphisms.how: Provides a blueprint for adaptive, distributed organization.
Interprets and sometimes alters the system’s recursive processes.
Presents changing conditions that require ongoing adjustment.

recursive_refinement.question: What does cybernetic feedback enable?
recursive_refinement.answer: The emergence of autonomy and adaptive self-regulation.

recursive_refinement.question: What does autonomy require?
recursive_refinement.answer: Ethical constraints to guide self-organization and prevent harm.

recursive_refinement.question: What new entanglement does this produce?
recursive_refinement.answer: A dynamic interplay between liberty, constraint, adaptation, and ethical responsibility in technical systems.

olog.thesis: Liberty machines—systems structured by cybernetic feedback and ethical constraint—embody the potential and paradoxes of autonomous, adaptive, and responsible technologies (Bateson, Wiener, Beer, von Foerster).
olog.problem_statement: How can we design and govern technical systems that support both autonomy and ethical responsibility in complex, changing environments?
vectors_of_influence: Challenges simplistic views of automation and control in technology.
Enables new models for organizational, technical, and ethical design (Beer, Bateson, von Foerster).
Connects to broader debates in cybernetics, systems theory, and the philosophy of technology.
olog.olog_prompt: For any liberty machine, identify all agents, feedback processes, and constraints; specify all morphisms that enable, require, or structure autonomy and adaptation; for each, describe what is transformed, how, and why it matters; recursively refine by asking what each process enables or requires, and what new entanglements are produced; conclude with a thesis, problem statement, and connection to broader systems.
